title: 110_s538
content: The Act may be cited as the "Work, Hope, and Opportunity for the Disaster Area Today Act." It includes a reduction in income tax withholding deposits to reflect FICA payroll tax credit for certain employers located in specified portions of the GO Zone during 2007. The Act, known as the "Work, Hope, and Opportunity for the Disaster Area Today Act," allows eligible employers to reduce income tax deposits by the payroll tax credit equivalent amount for a specific calendar quarter. This reduction also affects deductions allowable under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for taxes paid with respect to employment during the same quarter. Eligible employers are considered to have paid wages or compensation that were deducted but not deposited. The Act allows eligible employers to reduce income tax deposits by the payroll tax credit equivalent amount for a specific calendar quarter. Any excess amount is carried over to the next quarter or used to reduce deposits in future quarters. The payroll tax credit equivalent amount is 7.65 percent of wages or compensation. The Act allows eligible employers to reduce income tax deposits by the payroll tax credit equivalent amount for a specific calendar quarter. The amount of wages or compensation paid to eligible employees during the quarter is subject to the tax imposed by the Internal Revenue Code. There is a limitation on the wages subject to the credit, with a maximum of $15,000 per eligible employee in an applicable calendar quarter. Eligible employer refers to any employer with an active trade or business in specified portions of the GO Zone, employing up to 100 full-time employees. Eligible employee is defined as an employee whose main workplace is in the specified portions of the GO Zone. For purposes of the GO Zone incentives, the term "applicable calendar quarter" refers to any of the 4 calendar quarters starting in 2007. Special rules include definitions for "required income tax deposits" and application of aggregation rules similar to section 52 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Secretary of the Treasury will establish rules for eligible employers not on a quarterly system for income tax deposits. Regulations will also cover adjustments for acquisitions of businesses after December 31, 2006. After December 31, 2006, if an employer disposes of a major portion of a trade or business in a transaction, the acquiring employer's wages or compensation will be increased by the amount attributable to the acquired portion. If an employer disposes of a trade or business, the acquiring person's wages will be adjusted accordingly. This rule does not apply to government employers. The rules of subsections (d) and (e) of section 52 of the Code apply to entities other than government employers. Section 3 of the Act introduces a bonus business travel deduction in specified portions of the GO Zone, allowing for expenses incurred before January 1, 2010, in certain areas. The amendments apply to expenses paid after the enactment of the Act in taxable years ending after that date. Extension of increased expensing for qualified Section 179 Gulf Opportunity Zone property in specified portions of the GO Zone. Extension of increased expensing for qualified Section 179 Gulf Opportunity Zone property in specified portions of the GO Zone, with amendments to include certain property in the definition of section 179 property. The text chunk refers to the extension of increased expensing for qualified Section 179 Gulf Opportunity Zone property in specified portions of the GO Zone, with amendments to include certain property in the definition of section 179 property for the years 2007 and 2008. SEC. 5. Extension of Work Opportunity Tax Credit for Hurricane Katrina employees hired by small businesses in specified portions of the GO Zone. The Work Opportunity Tax Credit is extended for employees hired in specified areas affected by Hurricane Katrina. The Work Opportunity Tax Credit is extended to employees hired in specified areas affected by Hurricane Katrina, including those in the GO Zone with no more than 100 employees. The amendment takes effect as if included in the Katrina Emergency Tax Relief Act of 2005. SEC. 6. Extension and modification of 15-year straight-line cost recovery for qualified leasehold improvements and qualified restaurant improvements located in specified portions of the GO Zone; 15-year straight-line cost recovery for certain improvements to retail space located in specified portions of the GO Zone. Extension of Leasehold and Restaurant Improvements: Amendments are made to extend the timeframe for certain property placed in service in specified portions of the GO Zone. The modification also includes treating qualified restaurant property as 15-year property for depreciation deduction purposes, including new construction. The amendment extends the timeframe for certain property in specified areas of the GO Zone. Qualified restaurant property is treated as 15-year property for depreciation purposes, including new construction. The amendment extends the timeframe for certain property in specified areas of the GO Zone, including qualified restaurant property treated as 15-year property for depreciation purposes. This applies to any property placed in service after the enactment of the Act. The amendment extends the timeframe for certain property in specified areas of the GO Zone, including qualified retail improvement property placed in service before January 1, 2009. The amendment extends the timeframe for qualified retail improvement property if open to the general public and used in retail trade, placed in service more than 3 years after the building was first placed in service. Improvements made by the owner qualify only as long as held by the owner. The amendment extends the timeframe for qualified retail improvement property if open to the general public and used in retail trade, placed in service more than 3 years after the building was first placed in service. Improvements made by the owner qualify only as long as held by the owner. Certain improvements not included in the term shall not include any improvement for which the expenditure is attributable to the enlargement of the building, any elevator or escalator, any structural component benefitting a common area, or the internal structural framework of the building. The amendment to 168(g)(3)(B) extends the timeframe for qualified retail improvement property, excluding certain types of improvements. The amendments made by this section apply to property placed in service after the enactment of this Act.
